head.supplied: 4/7/91. ¶ ¶ I mentioned, dear Mr Bradshaw, at the meeting last evening, ¶ that you would read your important treatise at the next meeting; and now am glad to learn, that you will favor us with a sec...

div.p:
I mentioned, dear Mr Bradshaw, at the meeting last evening,
A meeting of the Victorian Branch of the Royal Geographical Society of Australasia, 'for the purpose of hearing a report from the Antarctic Exploration Committee'. that you would read your important treatise at the next meeting; and now am glad to learn, that you will favor us with a second essay then also.
At the 21st ordinary meeting of the Victorian Branch, held on 10 September 1891, Bradshaw read a paper, 'Notes of a recent trip to Prince Regent's River', in which he reported his discovery of the form of Aboriginal rock art now often referred to as 'Bradshaw figures'. The meeting was adjourned before he could read his second paper, 'The Future of North Australia', which he read instead at the continuation of the meeting held on 19 September. See Bradshaw (1892) and Bradshaw (1892a).
On 10 November 1891, the Secretary-General of the Société de Géographie, Paris, Charles Maunoir, wrote to Bradshaw, informing him that M had sent the Society an extract from the Daily telegraph with the account of his journey to the Prince Regent River (Daily telegraph (Melbourne), 12 September 1891, p. 10), and inviting him to send in due course 'the full account of your journey' for deposit in the Society's library (Bradshaw correspondence, private hands). A short extract was published in Comptes rendus des séances de la Société de géographie in the report of its meeting of 22 April 1892, p. 193. M seems also to have sent a copy of the Daily telegraph report to Gotha, since an account of Bradshaw's journey seemingly based on this report was published there, in Petermann's geographische Mitteilungen, vol. 37, pp. 319-21, in the issue that closed on 13 December 1891.

I have forwarded to Mr Macdonald your kind letter,
Letter not found. and asked him, to inform Mr Panton also of your further friendly intention, and to place that Gentleman in communication with you.
